item.title: Microseismicity in South Island, New Zealand
item.description: Seismicity rate changes when the stress state in the crust changes. Both seismicity and geodetic data are readily available to us.

item.title: Dieterich.JGR.1994
item.description: A constitutive law for rate of earthquake production and its application to earthquake clustering Authors: [[notes/James H Dieterich|James H. Dieterich]] Source Notes The essential concept of the analysis is the treatment of a seismically active volume of the Earth as having a population of sources that nucleate successive earthquakes to produce observed seismicity.

item.title: Earthquake Simulator
item.description: Input: fault slip from geodesy Output of fault seismicity that is often compared with [[notes/ETAS|ETAS]] Assumptions Faults do not grow or disappear !

item.title: Magnitude-frequency distribution
item.description: The distribution of earthquake sizes is an important quantity, particularly for seismic hazard assessment. Because it tells you the probability of large but infrequent earthquake if you can capture and measure the small ones.

item.title: Simulate earthquake sequences in 3-D fault systems
item.description: How to create a [[notes/modeling earthquakes|synthetic seismic sequence]]? Surely one can use the statistics to generate one. But we know plates move and faults slide.
